page.title: 11Origins of East Kilbride
page.content: Thirty three years ago the population of East Kilbride was just 2400. Now it is the sixth largest town in Scotland with a population of 72000 housed in 23000 houses which have been built in seven residential neighbourhoods. The name Kilbride derives from Kil from the Gaelic 'cil' (church or bury- ing place) and St Bryde who, although Irish, is well known in the folklore of Scotland and is said to have died at Abernethy about 451 AD. The New Town dates from a Draft Order of October 1946 which designated 10250 acres as the site of a proposed New Town under the New Towns Act of 1946. The New Town (East Kilbride) Designation Order was made on 6 May 1947 and East Kilbride was thus Scotland's first New Town.
